message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The congenital malformation described is consistent with Ebstein's anomaly, which has been associated with lithium use during pregnancy. None of the other medications listed have been associated with this malformation.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shown in the question is characteristic of Ebstein anomaly, which has been associated with maternal lithium use during pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The congenital malformation of the heart is most likely Ebstein anomaly, which has been associated with maternal lithium use during pregnancy. Lithium is commonly used to treat mood disorders. None of the other options are known to cause congenital heart defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image and symptoms described suggest the baby has Ebstein's anomaly, which is associated with maternal use of Lithium during pregnancy. Buspirone, Clozapine, and Enalapril are not known to cause this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows a chest radiograph of a newborn with a congenital heart defect known as Ebstein anomaly. Lithium is known to cause Ebstein anomaly in newborns if taken during pregnancy. None of the other options have been associated with congenital heart defects.

The congenital malformation of the heart described in the question is consistent with Ebstein's anomaly, which is associated with maternal use of lithium during pregnancy. The other medication options do not have known associations with this congenital malformation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The congenital heart malformation with apical displacement of the septa and posterior tricuspid valve leaflets is consistent with Ebstein anomaly, which is associated with Lithium use during pregnancy. None of the other medications listed are known to cause this malformation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cyanotic baby with congenital heart disease suggests in utero exposure to a teratogenic drug, and among the options, only lithium has been associated with Ebstein’s anomaly.
